sen.j: 大野果安（おおののはたやす、生没年不明）は、日本の飛鳥時代の人物である。
sen.e: ONO no Hatayasu was active in the Asuka period of Japan (year of birth and death unknown).
ONO no Hatayasu was a figure in the Asuka period of Japan (year of birth and death unknown).
sen.cmt: activeをa figureに変更しました。
sen.e: ONO no Hatayasu was a figure in the Asuka period of Japan (year of birth and death unknown).

sen.j: 旧仮名遣いでの読みは「おほののはたやす」。
sen.e: In old Japanese syllabary characters, his name had been written as Ohono no Hatayasu, and it is considered to have been pronounced as Ofono no Fatayasu.
sen.cmt: 飛鳥時代は、は行をFで発音していたのでOfono no Fatayasuとなります。
sen.e: In old Japanese orthography, his name had been written as Ohono no Hatayasu, and it is considered to have been pronounced as Ofono no Fatayasu.
sen.cmt: 「旧仮名遣い」をデータベースに合わせ、old Japanese orthographyとしました。
sen.e: In old Japanese orthography, his name had been written as Ohono no Hatayasu, and it is considered to have been pronounced as Ofono no Fatayasu.
His kabane (hereditary title) was Kimi.
His kabane (hereditary title) was Kimi.
His kabane (hereditary title) was Kimi.

sen.j: 672年の壬申の乱では大友皇子（弘文天皇）側の将となり、乃楽山（奈良市）で大伴吹負を破ったが、倭京を前にして引き上げた。
sen.e: In the Jinshin War of 672, Hatayasu supported Otomo no Miko (Prince Otomo who has been called Emperor Kobun since the Meiji era); he became a general and defeated OTOMO no Fukei at Mt. Nara (present Nara City), however, before advancing to Yamato City, he withdrew.
sen.cmt: オリジナルに「及楽山」とありましたが、正しくは「乃楽山」なので直します。
sen.e: Although he fought for Otomo no Miko (Prince Otomo who has been called Emperor Kobun since the Meiji era) as a general and defeated OTOMO no Fukei at Mt. Nara (present Nara City) in the Jinshin War of 672, he withdrew before reaching the City of Yamato.
sen.cmt: Althoughで書き換えました。「を前に」はbefore reachingにしました。「倭京」はデータベースに従いました。
sen.e: Although he fought for Otomo no Miko (Prince Otomo who has been called Emperor Kobun since the Meiji era) as a general and defeated OTOMO no Fukei at Mt. Nara (present Nara City) in the Jinshin War of 672, he withdrew before reaching the City of Yamato.

sen.j: その後、糾職大夫、直広肆。
sen.e: Later he became Jikikoshi Kyushiki-daibu (internal inspector at fifth rank).
Later he became Jikikoshi Kyushiki-daibu (internal inspector at fifth rank).
Later he became Jikikoshi Kyushiki-daibu (internal inspector at fifth rank).

sen.j: 大野氏は、上毛野氏の支族である。
sen.e: The Ono clan was a branch family of the Kamitsukeno clan.
sen.cmt: 上毛野Kamitsukeno…岩波文庫『日本書紀』の読みに従います。
sen.e: The Ono clan was a branch family of the Kamitsukeno clan.
The Ono clan was a branch family of the Kamitsukeno clan.

sen.j: 果安の子としては大野東人がいる。
sen.e: ONO no Azumahito was Hatayasu's son.
He had a son, ONO no Azumahito.
He had a son, ONO no Azumahito.

sen.j: 壬申の乱のとき、果安は大友皇子を戴く近江朝廷の将となった。
sen.e: At the Jinshin War, Hatayasu was appointed to a general by the Omi court which supported Otomo no Miko (Prince Otomo).
At the Jinshin War, Hatayasu was appointed to a general by the Omi court with Otomo no Miko (Prince Otomo) at the top.
At the Jinshin War, Hatayasu was appointed to a general by the Omi court with Otomo no Miko (Prince Otomo) at the top.

sen.j: 大海人皇子（天武天皇）に味方した大伴吹負が倭京（飛鳥の古い都）を制圧して北上したとき、大野果安は北から奈良盆地に進入した。
sen.e: When OTOMO no Fukei, who supported Oama no Miko (Oshiama no Miko or Prince Oama who became Emperor Tenmu following the victory in the war), controlled Yamato City (the old capital of Asuka) and went north, ONO no Hatayasu came to Nara Basin from the north.

When OTOMO no Fukei, who supported Oama no Miko (Oshiama no Miko or Prince Oama who became Emperor Tenmu following the victory in the war), took the City of Yamato (the old capital of Asuka) in control and moved toward the north, ONO no Hatayasu approached the Nara Basin from the north.

When OTOMO no Fukei, who supported Oama no Miko (Oshiama no Miko or Prince Oama who became Emperor Tenmu following the victory in the war), took the City of Yamato (the old capital of Asuka) in control and moved toward the north, ONO no Hatayasu approached the Nara Basin from the north.

sen.j: 果安は、乃楽山（ならやま、奈良の山）に陣を敷いた吹負と戦い、これを破った。
sen.e: Fukei camped at Mt. Nara, and Hatayasu defeated Fukei's army there.
sen.cmt: オリジナルに「及楽山」とありましたが、正しくは「乃楽山」なので直します。
sen.e: Fukei camped at Mt. Nara, and Hatayasu defeated Fukei's army there.
Fukei camped at Mt. Nara, and Hatayasu defeated Fukei's army there.

sen.j: 果安は追撃して八口に至り、高地にのぼって倭京を見下ろした。
sen.e: Hatayasu went after Fukei to Yakuchi to defeat his army, and went up to a hill to see Yamato City.
Hatayasu went after Fukei to Yakuchi to defeat his army, and went up to a hill to look down on the City of Yamato.
sen.cmt: 「倭京を見下ろす」を訳出しました。
sen.e: Hatayasu went after Fukei to Yakuchi to defeat his army, and went up to a hill to look down on the City of Yamato.

sen.j: 果安は街路に楯が並べられているのを見て伏兵を疑い、引き返した。
sen.e: Hatayasu noticed shields standing at each road and was afraid of Fukei's ambush, therefore, withdrew his army.
As Hatayasu noticed shields standing at each road, he was so afraid of Fukei's ambush that he turned back.
sen.cmt: As節を使って書き換えました。
sen.e: As Hatayasu noticed shields standing at each road, he was so afraid of Fukei's ambush that he turned back.

sen.j: その楯は、乃楽山の戦いの前に荒田尾赤麻呂と忌部子人が並べたもので、京を守る兵力は少なかった。
sen.e: In fact, those shields were placed by ARATAO no Akamaro and IMIBE no Kobito before the battle at Mt. Nara, and the real force for guarding the city was very poor and undermanned.
sen.cmt: オリジナルに「及楽山」とありましたが、正しくは「乃楽山」なので直します。
sen.e: In fact, those shields were placed by ARATAO no Akamaro and IMIBE no Kobito before the battle at Mt. Nara, and the real force for guarding the city was very poor and undermanned.
In fact, those shields were placed by ARATAO no Akamaro and IMIBE no Kobito before the battle at Mt. Nara, and the real force for guarding the city was very poor and undermanned.

sen.j: 果安の逡巡のおかげで、吹負は援軍と合流し敗走した兵を集める猶予を得た。
sen.e: Since Hatayasu hesitated to advance, Fukei was given a time to join the reinforcements and gathered the withdrawn soldiers.
The hesitation of Hatayasu gave Fukei time to join the reinforcements and gather the withdrawing soldiers.
sen.cmt: 主語をthe hesitationにして書き換えました。
sen.e: The hesitation of Hatayasu gave Fukei time to join the reinforcements and gather the withdrawing soldiers.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』に記される大野果安の事績はこれだけで、この後にこの方面の軍の総指揮官として現れるのは犬養五十君である。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki" (Chronicle of Japan), further achievements of Hatayasu are not found, and instead of him, INUKAI no Ikimi's achievements as a general supporting Otomo no Miko were described in detail.
sen.cmt: 犬養五十君INUKAI no Ikimi…「いそきみ」ではなく「いきみ」
sen.e: "Nihonshoki" (Chronicle of Japan) includes no further achievement of Hatayasu in it, but that of INUKAI no Ikimi as a general supporting this area instead.
sen.cmt: "Nihonshoki"を主語にして書き換えました。
sen.e: "Nihonshoki" (Chronicle of Japan) includes no further achievement of Hatayasu in it, but that of INUKAI no Ikimi as a general supporting this area instead.

sen.j: 果安は更迭されたのかもしれないが、五十君の指揮下に入っただけなのかもしれない。
sen.e: Hatayasu might have been dismissed or supported Ikimi's army.
Hatayasu might have been dismissed or under Ikimi's command.
Hatayasu might have been dismissed or under Ikimi's command.

sen.j: 乱の後、大野果安は赦されて天武天皇や持統天皇に仕えたらしい。
sen.e: After the war, ONO no Hatayasu is considered to have been forgiven and served Emperor Tenmu and Empress Jito.
After the war, ONO no Hatayasu is considered to have been forgiven and served Emperor Tenmu and Empress Jito.
After the war, ONO no Hatayasu is considered to have been forgiven and served Emperor Tenmu and Empress Jito.

sen.j: 『続日本紀』は天平14年（742年）11月2日に死んだ大野東人の説明に、「飛鳥朝廷の糺職大夫、直広肆果安の子なり」と記す。
sen.e: According to "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), ONO no Azumahito died on November 2, 742, and he was a son of Jikikoshi Hatayasu who had served as Kyushiki-daibu (internal inspector) in the Asuka Dynasty.

According to "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), ONO no Azumahito died on December 7, 742, and he was 'a son of Jikikoshi Hatayasu who had served as Kyushiki-daibu (internal inspector) in the Asuka Dynasty.'
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更し、一重括弧部分にシングルクォーテーションを補足しました。
sen.e: According to "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), ONO no Azumahito died on December 7, 742, and he was 'a son of Jikikoshi Hatayasu who had served as Kyushiki-daibu (internal inspector) in the Asuka Dynasty.'
